case_vignette: A 32-year-old male with past medical history of poorly controlled HIV presents to clinic with dark spots on the skin and in the mouth. He cannot recall when they first started. He denies any drug or alcohol use. He is not currently taking his antiretroviral therapy. Examination reveals multiple ovoid violaceous ruddy, brown ovoid macules on the trunk, legs, oral palate and plantar feet. A punch biopsy is performed and stains for HHV-8 is positive.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have dark spots on my skin and in my mouth.
When did you first notice these dark spots?
I cannot recall when they first started.
Have the dark spots increased in number or size over time?
I didn't mention observing any changes in the number or size of the spots.
Do you have any known allergies or other underlying health conditions?
I have a history of poorly controlled HIV.
Are there other family members with similar symptoms?
I didn't mention anything about other family members having similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Kaposi's sarcoma
